intro: Phaca purshii subsp. tincta, commonly known as the purple phaca, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems. The plant produces small, white to pale purple flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from June to August. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, with a distinctive, slightly bitter scent. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes.
